abstract.text: Properties used by the functions described in getting and setting pieces of data in audio files. See Working with Global Information for details.

abstract.text: Record or play audio, convert formats, parse audio streams, and configure your audio session.
A type of marker within a file used in the
field of the
structure.
The playback direction of a looped segment of an audio file.
Access these properties using the functions described in Working with Global Information.
Annotates a position in an audio file.
Flags for use when opening an audio file.
Flags that specify a playback direction for an audio file region structure.
Operating system constants that indicate the type of file to be written or a hint about what type of file to expect from data provided.
Writes bytes of audio data to an audio file.
Writes packets of audio data to an audio data file.
Read or write a variety of audio data to or from disk or a memory buffer.
Flags to set when creating an audio file.
Flags specified in a packet translation structure.
Key values of properties to get and set using Audio File Services functions and provide a common way to get the same information out of several different kinds of files.
An object containing the image data for the album artwork associated with an audio file.
Indicates the number of bytes of audio data in the designated file.
Indicates the number of packets of audio data in the designated file.
The actual bit rate (number of audio data bits in the file divided by the duration of the file) for some file types, and the nominal bit rate (which bit rate the encoder was set to) for others.
Passes an audio byte packet translation structure with the
field filled out and returns the
and
fields. If the value in the
field is an estimate then the
flag is set in the
field.
An audio channel layout structure.
An array of  four-character codes for each kind of chunk in the file.
An audio stream basic description containing the format of the audio data.
This constant is deprecated in macOS 10.5 and later. Do not use. Instead, use
(declared in the
header file).
Indicates the byte offset in the file of the designated audio data.
The default value (
) always updates header. If set to

, updating the files sizes in the header is not performed every time data is written. Instead, the updating is deferred until the file has been read, optimized, or closed. This process is more efficient, but not as safe. If an application crashes before the size has been updated, the file might not be readable.

An estimated duration in seconds. If this duration can be calculated without scanning the entire file, or all the audio data packets have been scanned, the value accurately reflects the duration of the audio data.
The format of the audio data file.
To support formats such as AAC SBR in which an encoded data stream can be decoded to multiple destination formats, this propertyâ€™s value is an array of audio format list item values (declared in
) of those formats. Typically, this is an audio format list item with the same audio stream basic description in the
property.
Passes an audio frame packet translation structure with the
field filled out and returns the
and
fields.
A
value pointing to memory set up by your application to contain a fully formatted ID3 tag.
A CF Dictionary with information about the data in the file.
Indicates whether a designated audio file has been optimized, that is, ready to start having sound data written to it. A value of
indicates the file needs to be optimized. A value of
indicates the file is currently optimized.
A pointer to memory set up by the caller. Some file types require that a magic cookie be provided before packets can be written to an audio file. Set this property before you call
or
if a magic cookie exists.
A list of audio file markers defined in the file.
Indicates the maximum size of a packet for the data in the designated file.
The theoretical maximum packet size in the file. This value is obtained without actually scanning the whole file to find the largest packet, as could happen with
Gets or sets an audio file packet table information structure for its supporting file types. When setting the structure, the sum of the values of the
and
fields must be the same as the total number of frames in all packets. If not, a
is returned. To ensure this result, get the value of the property and make sure the sum of the three values you set has the same sum as the three values you got.
Passes an audio byte packet translation structure with the
field filled out and returns the
field. The
field is ignored. If the value in the
field is an estimate then the
flag is set in the
field.
Passes an audio frame packet translation structure with the
field filled out and returns the
field. The
field is ignored.
The list of audio file region values defined in the file.

The duration in seconds of the data expected to be written. Set this property before any data has been written to reserve space in the file header for a packet table and other information to appear before the audio data. Otherwise, the packet table might get written at the end of the file, preventing the file from being streamable.
For compressed data, this propertyâ€™s value is the bit depth of the source, uncompressed audio stream as an
value, if known. The bit depth is expressed as a negative number if the uncompressed source was in a floating point format. For example, a property value of
is used for
and a property value of
represents
